column1: Neuro-myths matter because they affect people's thoughts and behavior: they can change how we see ourselves and how we see each other. Let us take the example of gender again. At age 8 to 9
column2: there is no difference in how well girls and boys do at math
column3: yet girls (and their parents) rate their math ability to be lower than boys. This suggests that what people believe (in this case
column4: that girls are not as strong at math) may have a real impact on how children see themselves
column5: which may in turn affect their actual performance. In one study
column6: when a group of college students was given a math test
column7: men did better than women when they were told that the test usually shows gender differences
column8: but when they were told it was a gender-fair test
column9: women did just as well as men. This is important because
column11: differences that were once small become massive: 94% of maths professors in the UK are men . This is a good example of why we should be careful about neuro-myths—what you believe about your brain and the brains of those around you may just come true.
